about_rhodes.title: About Rhodes
about_rhodes.paragraph1: Rhodes, the Island of the Sun, has been a crossroads of civilizations for millennia. From Antiquity and the founding of the city-state of Rhodes in 408 BC to the Roman and Byzantine periods, the island has always played a key role in the Eastern Mediterranean.
about_rhodes.paragraph2: Its Medieval Town, with well-preserved walls and the Palace of the Grand Master, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a living treasure of the Knights of St. John.
about_rhodes.paragraph3: The island is characterized by a variaty of landscape: mountain villages, forests, gorges, and extended coastlines. The Valley of the Butterflies, the forest of Prophet Elias, and beaches such as Tsambika or Prasonisi attact vititors for many reasons, from hiking and relaxation to water sports.
about_rhodes.paragraph4: Rhodes maintains a strong cultural identity, expressed both through daily life and organized events. Festivals, local cultural groups, and traditional dances bring life to every part of the island. Its gastronomy is based on products like olive oil, honey, and wine, and includes traditional dishes such as pitaroudia and melekounia.
quick_facts: Climate : Mediterranean - mild winters, hot summers
fun_facts: Rhodes is the 4th largest island in Greece
It enjoys over 300 days of sunshine per year
It was home to one of the Seven Worders of the Ancient World, the Colossus of Rhodes
